Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effects of Check Dams on Landscape and Society - A Catalyzing Visit to the Eco-Sensitive Shiwalik Foothills of India
Award.AbstractNarration: This CNIC award supports the U.S.-India Collaborative Research: Effects of Check Dams on Landscape and Society-a Catalyzing Visit to the Eco-Sensitive Shiwalik Foothills of India. PI Ranbir Kang, Western Illinois University and collaborator Elizabeth Chacko, George Washington University will initiate an international collaboration with Drs. Dhian Kaur and K.P. Singh from the Departments of Geography and Geology at Panjab University to study the geophysical and socio-economic impacts of check dams in the Punjab. The research team will gather data on the effects of check dams on channel morphology, surrounding land cover, ground water levels, and local populations. They will use official government and NGO data on agriculture, demographics, hydrology, vegetation, as well as, focus groups and local inhabitants to understand the effects of check dams on socio-economic progress and perceptions of ecological change. The proposed research is novel in that it will analyze not only the human-environment impacts of check dams in a sub-tropical developing area, but also the feed-back mechanisms between humans and the environment in such a locale. Two US graduate students will participate in the field research in India. Findings from this study will be used to refine research questions and hypotheses for a fully developed research proposal to be submitted to NSF's Geography and Spatial Systems(GSS)Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Small check dams in hilly locales experiencing environmental degradation due to deforestation and flooding may be a key for socio-economic resilience for such areas. Our team visited six such check dams in Shiwalik foot hills in India which is an underpriviledged area with relatively high proportions of disempowered populations. These check dams included three small dams (Sukho Majri, Rel Majra, and Dhamala) and three relatively large dams (Perch, Siswans, and Bunga). Our field work in these reservoirs and their catchment areas revealed that these dams have reduced the flooding by serving as sediment sinks. As a result, they are experiencing sedimentation which is primarily through tributaries. At the same time, the forest cover as well as wild life has increased in these areas. Due to reduced flooding and formation of water reservoirs, the cropping diversity has increased from millet and maize in these areas to millet, maize, wheat, and rice. Farmers are also growing many vegetables and fruits in this area. While these dams have improved the economic conditions of local communities, their benefits are not equally distributed. Our findings also revealed that level of the involvement of local community could potentially affect the life span of such check dams. Their proximity to major highways is another factor that may dictate the degree of the effects of check dams on local communities.
